guide.title: Gentoo Guide to USE flags
guide.abstract: This guide introduces you to the ultimate tool for customizing Gentoo -- USE settings. Not only is there a description of each USE flag in current use, there is also a helpful guide to help you to determine which USE flags you will need to use.

section.title: What is the use of USE flags anyway?

body.p: One of the things which attracted me, as a user, to Gentoo was the fact that it is a highly customisable distribution. The fact that it is a source based distribution allows the user complete control over what kinds of features and support are built in to the installed applications. Moreover, the idea of bloat reduction appealed to me -- I like not having to install things which I do not really need.

And how, exactly, does Gentoo achieve this? By defining USE settings. Essentially, these are keywords that define options used on a system-wide basis to configure applications during their respective compilation procedures.
Of course, Gentoo defines a set of safe default flags for you. You will find these in your /etc/make.profile/make.defaults file.
From the Gentoo-1.1a release, the USE settings are:
body.pre: USE="xv slang readline gpm berkdb mmx 3dnow gdbm tcpd pam libwww ssl nls mitshm arts lame perl python esd gif imlib sdl oggvorbis gnome gtk X qt kde motif opengl avi png tiff gif"
body.warn:
Instead of writing to this file, as I can see many of you scrambling to do, it is advisable procedure to edit your /etc/make.conf file
In that file, you will see:
body.p: You would uncomment it by removing the # and adding your own custom USE flags to that string between the quotes.
body.impo: Remember that -flag disables a flag and flag adds a flag. If a flag is neither in /etc/make.profile/make.defaults nor in /etc/make.conf then its functionality is disabled.
body.p: Simply uncomment that, and add whatever other flags you want to add. "But what if I want to remove things from the make.defaults file?" I hear you ask. That is simply done by putting "-flag" in your /etc/make.conf file. Mine, for example, looks like this:
body.pre: USE="-gnome -kde qt -arts -nls python perl oggvorbis opengl sdl -postgres jpeg png truetype xml xml2 dvd avi aalib mpeg encode fbcon mmx"
body.p: Now that you know how to enable extra flags, and disable existing flags, let us examine what these flags actually do.

For your processor, you have three flags: mmx, 3dnow, and sse. 3dnow is applicable to certain AMD K-6 cpus and Athlon and higher cpus. mmx is applicable to Pentium-MMX class and higher cpus, including Athlons. sse is a feature for higher Pentiums. If you have a Pentium4 with SSE2, you want this flag as well.

Now, for your video card. If you have a 3dfx card, you want to enable the 3dfx flag. If your card is a voodoo3 then you want to enable the voodoo3 flag.
If you have a matrox card, you want the matrox flag enabled.
Laptop users will probably want to enable the apm flag and the pcmcia flag. If you do not want CardBus support, then enable the nocardbus flag as well. The pnp support gives you PNP in pcmcia-cs.
If you have a Palm Pilot or PDA that you like to interface with your Gentoo machine, then the pda flag is for you.
If you intend to attach a digital camera, then the gphoto2 flag will cause support for it to be compiled into relevant applications.
Finally, if you have a printer, then the cups flag will build printer support. And slp will add Service Locator Protocol support to CUPS.

If you intend to use the XFree86 system, then the flag X is a good idea. With X, you can enable the dga flag to get Direct Graphic Access optimisation. The opengl flag exists for enabling the OpenGL support in many applications. XFree86 can be made to support the XVideo extension if you enable the xv USE flag. According to one of the visitors in the #gentoo IRC channel at openprojects.net ([Nagash]), "xv makes Mplayer good."
If you want to have support for the framebuffer console (as provided by the kernel -- the penguin at boot time is an example), then enable the fbcon flag.
If you would like to be able to use certain applications with DirectFB, then the directfb flag needs to be enabled.
Are you a KDE user? Then the following flags are for you:
kde -- to build KDE support
qt -- to allow linking to the Qt libraries
qtmt -- to allow linking to the multi-threaded version of the Qt libraries
arts -- the KDE sound system
body.impo: Please note that if you do not want KDE support, you must disable at least kde and arts support.
body.p: Do you prefer GNOME? Then use:
gnome -- to build apps with GNOME support
gtk -- to build apps with GTK+ support
There are many more flags for GNOME users.
bonobo -- support for GNOME's CORBA interface through Bonobo
evo -- support for Evolution (Gnome's Outlook-like application)
gb -- support for Gnome Basic (such a thing actually exists??)
gtkhtml -- support for the mis-named GTK-HTML library
body.warn: To disable GNOME support, simply add -gnome to your USE string in /etc/make.conf

body.p: There are many many libraries that provide multimedia. Let us deal with the graphics libraries first. In the previous section we saw GTK and Qt toolkit library support. Other available options are:
motif -- for OpenMotif support
tcltk -- for Tcl and/or Tk support
aalib -- support for ascii graphics.
imlib -- support for the Imlib image loading and rendering library.
ncurses -- support for the ncurses console display - many applications offer the user a choice of front-ends, and ncurses is a popular (and safe) one
readline -- another console based library.
sdl -- this is the Simple Direct Layer media library -- many excellent games are compiled against this library.
svga -- Some applications can offer SVGAlib support
lcms -- offers color management support to the imagemagick library
You can add support for different graphics formats with the following flags:
gif -- support for GIF image format using libungif or giflib
jpeg -- support for JPEG image format using libjpeg
png -- support for PNG image format
tiff -- support for TIFF image format
So you like to watch movies? Then you might be interested in enabling some of the optional support offered with the following flags:
avi -- adds support from the avifile library, and optionally the Win32 codec library
mpeg -- adds support from the libmpeg3 library
quicktime -- adds support from the OpenQuickTime and Quicktime4Linux libraries.
There are many sound layer libraries on offer.
alsa -- the Advanced Linux Sound Architecture
esd -- the Enlightened Sound Daemon
mikmod -- a library to allow MikMod sound modules support
oss -- the Open Sound System
nas -- Network Audio Sound
ggi -- support for non-X video drivers for movie playing
dvd -- adds support for playing and decrypting DVDs using the libcss library
xmms - the X MultiMedia System
oggvorbis -- support for the Ogg Vorbis audio format
flash -- support for creating flash files usng Ming
encode -- if you like to be able to encode various multimedia formats
Of course, you want to connect your Gentoo box to a net of some sort.
ipv6 -- builds support for IPv6
snmp -- support for Simple Network Management Protocol, which allows you to manage remote machines.
If you are concerned about security, we recommend PAM support provided by:
pam -- Pluggable Authentication Modules
ssl -- Secure Socket Layer -- necessary for ssh. Apache also supports this, as do mail readers to establish secure connections.
crypt -- To provide mcrypt, mhash and gpg encryption library support
socks5 -- build Socks5 support

section.title: MAIL FLAGS
section.body:
imap -- support for IMAP
ldap -- adds Lightweight Directory Accesss Protocol support
tcpd -- support for TCP wrappers
xface -- support for xface (images sent along with e-mail messages) support to sylpheed and sylpheed-claws

body.p: mozilla -- Adds Mozilla support to other applications
When emerging mozilla, you may want to keep the following flags in mind:
mozaccess-builtin -- Adds to text-to-speech and eventually braille support
mozctl -- Adds Pango like module to mozilla
mozirc -- adds an IRC (Internet Relay Chat) module
mozxmlterm -- Adds an xterm like terminal with XML support
spell -- to add ispell/aspell/pspell support for spell-checking
truetype -- to add support for FreeType and FreeType2 fonts
xml -- adds support for XML library (version 1)
xml2 -- adds support for GNOME's XML library (version 2)
pdflib -- adds support for Adobe's Portable Document Format
plotutils -- to add plotting in gnuplot
tetex -- adds support for TeTeX the best thing for publishing
guile -- Guile is an interpreter for Scheme
slang -- S-Lang is a powerful interpreted language
libwww -- general purpose web api
libg++ -- adds C++ modules

p.c: atlas -- Adds support for Automatically Tuned Linear Algebra Software instead of BLAS (Basic Linear Algebra Subprograms) for the R language. ATLAS is highly optimised for its architecture

body.p: You have a choice of database types that you get support for:
berkdb -- BerkleyDB for MySQL
mysql -- MySQL
postgres -- PostgreSQL
odbc -- Support for UnixODBC (Open Database Connectivity)
innodb -- MySQL transaction support
gd -- GNU database libraries
gdbm -- ditto
acl -- Support for SGI's XFS dump/restore utilities
afs -- OpenAFS, which is a distributed file system
samba -- Support for SAMBA (windows/unix interconnectivity)
nls -- Adds Native Language Support (usually using GNU's gettext libs); this is just bloatware if you only need one language.
doc -- causes extra documentation to be generated
gpm -- Adds General Purpose Mouse support for the console

The flags in this section are used in some ebuilds, but as of this writing, their meanings are unknown to the author. For any feedback regarding them or any other USE flags, please fill out a bug report at http://bugs.gentoo.org and assign it to seemant@gentoo.org
zeo -- Adds support for Zope Enterprise Objects
